column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Why were you specifically selected to co-write The America We Deserve ?
#Text=Got the job through the White House Writer 's Group .
#Text=I do n't know if this organization still exists . [
#Text=As of March 12 , 2016 , the group has a functioning website at www.whwg.com ]
#Text=What was it like to work with Donald Trump ?
#Text=Trump was a lot of fun .
#Text=Did n't seem to take himself too seriously .
#Text=He was most passionate about his fear of a terrorist attack on New York , which he talks about in the book .
#Text=How much input did Roger Stone have in the content of The America We Deserve ?
#Text=I wrote the book without any input from Stone .
#Text=Was there any indication that Trump was not serious about the campaign or did not want to run ?
#Text=I was under the impression that he was on a lark .
#Text=As I recall he ended his pursuit of the White House fairly soon after the book came out .
#Text=Russ Verney
#Text=Verney in 2008 .
#Text=Image : Bob Barr .
#Text=Wikinews reached out early this month to Russ Verney , who served as chairman of the Reform Party during Trump 's exploratory bid for the party 's presidential nomination in 2000 .
#Text=Verney previously worked on the 1992 presidential campaign of Ross Perot and became chairman of the Reform Party upon its founding by Perot in 1995 .
#Text=When Perot ran as the party 's presidential nominee in 1996 , he named Verney as campaign director .
#Text=Later , Verney headed the Perot faction of the party when a schism between Perot 's supporters and the supporters of Minnesota governor Jesse Ventura threatened to split the party .
#Text=With Trump potentially running as a member of the Ventura faction , Verney was initially dismissive of a Trump candidacy .
#Text=In a July 1999 interview with New York Daily News , he said party members were not drafting Trump for president and " never spent one second thinking about him . "
#Text=Later in the year , Verney commented he had not heard a " compelling reason [ ... ] for [ Trump ] to seek the presidency . "

#Text=After Trump invited members of the Reform Party , including Verney , to his compound outside Mar-a-Lago in Palm Beach , Florida in January 2000 , Verney praised Trump , expressing " [ t]his is him reaching out to all parts of the Reform Party , and that 's good . "
#Text=However , Trump continued attacks on Pat Buchanan , focusing largely on the support Buchanan garnered from former Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke .
#Text=These comments received greater attention in 2016 when Trump himself received an endorsement from Duke and the Ku Klux Klan .

#Text=Trump 's seeming inability to disavow the support in an interview with CNN ( despite an earlier disavowal ) formed part of the basis of the March 2016 speech in which Mitt Romney urged Republicans not to vote for Trump .
#Text=After Trump dropped out of the 2000 race , ceasing his attacks on Buchanan , Buchanan received 0.42 % of the general election vote , far below Perot 's 1996 showing of 8.40 % .
#Text=After the 2000 election , Verney left the party and began working as a regional director and national adviser for the conservative foundation Judicial Watch .
#Text=In 2008 , he worked as campaign manager for the presidential run of Libertarian Party nominee Bob Barr .
#Text=Recently , he was hired as executive director for Project Veritas , a conservative group known for investigative film journalism .

#Text=Verney answers questions about his meetings with Trump , responds to the accusation that Trump 's 2000 exploratory committee was a " dirty trick " to hurt the Reform Party , and analyzes Trump 's rise in the 2016 campaign .
